questions.question: Differentiate between kinetic energy and potential energy.
questions.answer: Kinetic energy: Energy possessed by a body by virtue of its motion. A moving car, flowing water, or a rolling ball has kinetic energy. It depends on mass and speed of the object. Potential energy: Energy stored in a body by virtue of its position or change in shape. A raised weight, stretched rubber band, or water stored in a dam has potential energy. It depends on mass, height, and gravitational force.
questions.source_section: Evaluation - E. Differentiate between

questions.question: Differentiate between work and energy.
questions.answer: Work: Work is done when a force is applied on a body and the body moves in the direction of the force. Work = Force × Displacement. Work is a process of energy transfer. Energy: Energy is the capacity to do work. It is possessed by a body and can be stored. When work is done on a body, its energy increases; when work is done by a body, its energy decreases.

questions.question: Define energy. What is its SI unit?
questions.answer: Energy is defined as the capacity to do work. When work is done by a body, its energy decreases, and when work is done on a body, its energy increases. The SI unit of energy is joule (J). One joule is the energy required to move an object through 1 metre against a force of 1 Newton. 1 J = 1 N × 1 m
questions.source_section: Evaluation - G. Short-answer-type questions

questions.question: State the law of conservation of energy.
questions.answer: According to the law of conservation of energy, energy can neither be created nor destroyed. The total amount of energy in a system always remains constant. It can only be transformed from one form to another. For example, when a ball is thrown up, kinetic energy is converted to potential energy, and when it falls down, potential energy is converted back to kinetic energy.
questions.source_section: Evaluation - G. Short-answer-type questions

questions.question: What are the two types of mechanical energy? Give one example of each.
questions.answer: The two types of mechanical energy are: 1) Kinetic energy - the energy possessed by a body due to its motion. Example: A moving car, a rolling ball, flowing water. 2) Potential energy - the energy stored in a body due to its position or change in shape. Example: Water stored in a dam, a stretched rubber band, a stone lifted above the ground.
questions.source_section: Evaluation - G. Short-answer-type questions

questions.question: What do you mean by transformation of energy?
questions.answer: The conversion of energy from one form to another is called transformation of energy or inter-conversion of energy. In almost every situation in daily life, energy is converted from one form to another. For example, in a thermal power plant, heat energy is converted to electrical energy. In an electric bulb, electrical energy is converted to light energy.
questions.source_section: Evaluation - G. Short-answer-type questions

questions.question: State two factors on which the kinetic energy of a moving body depends.
questions.answer: The kinetic energy of a moving body depends on: 1) Mass of the object - Greater the mass of an object, greater is its kinetic energy. A cricket ball moving at the same speed as a tennis ball has more kinetic energy because it has more mass. 2) Speed of the object - Faster the speed of a moving object, greater is its kinetic energy. A fast-moving tennis ball has more kinetic energy than a slow-moving tennis ball.
questions.source_section: Evaluation - G. Short-answer-type questions

questions.question: How do we hear sound?
questions.answer: Sound is produced by vibrating bodies. When an object vibrates, it causes the air particles around it to vibrate. These vibrations travel through the air as sound waves. When these sound waves reach our ears, they make the membrane inside the ear (eardrum) vibrate. These vibrations are then converted into signals that are sent to the brain, and we perceive sound. Sound energy is also capable of doing work as vibrations caused by sound are a type of motion.
questions.source_section: Evaluation - H. Long-answer-type questions

questions.question: Give one example for each of the following transformation of energy: (a) chemical energy to light energy (b) electrical energy to heat energy (c) mechanical energy to electrical energy (d) electrical energy to sound energy (e) light energy to chemical energy
questions.answer: (a) Chemical energy to light energy: Burning of a matchstick or firecracker - chemical energy stored in them is converted to light (and heat) energy. (b) Electrical energy to heat energy: Electric heaters, geysers, irons, and electric kettles convert electrical energy to heat energy. (c) Mechanical energy to electrical energy: Generators and dynamos convert mechanical energy to electrical energy. (d) Electrical energy to sound energy: Loudspeakers, electric bells, music systems, and telephone speakers convert electrical energy to sound energy. (e) Light energy to chemical energy: Photosynthesis in plants - light energy from the sun is converted to chemical energy stored in food.
questions.source_section: Evaluation - H. Long-answer-type questions

questions.question: The bob of a simple pendulum is swinging from its lowest position to its highest position. Which of the following statements is true about the motion of the bob?
questions.answer: (c) Potential energy will attain its maximum value and kinetic energy will attain its minimum value. When the bob moves from the lowest position to the highest position, it gains height and loses speed. At the highest position, it momentarily stops (zero kinetic energy) and has maximum potential energy.
options: Both kinetic and potential energy will be equal
Kinetic energy will attain its maximum value and potential energy will attain its minimum value
Potential energy will attain its maximum value and kinetic energy will attain its minimum value
Both kinetic and potential energy will attain their minimum value

questions.question: The given image illustrates the motion of a roller coaster. The roller coaster is pulled by a motor from point A to B. Even though there is no motor to pull the roller coaster from point C to D, it still moves through the loop. Identify the energy or energy conversions that take place: (a) from A to B (b) from C to D
questions.answer: (a) From A to B: Electrical energy from the motor is converted to mechanical energy (kinetic and potential energy) of the roller coaster. As the coaster rises from A to B, it gains potential energy. (b) From C to D: Potential energy at C is converted to kinetic energy as the coaster goes down, then back to potential energy as it rises through the loop. The total mechanical energy remains constant (law of conservation of energy), allowing the coaster to complete the loop without a motor.
questions.source_section: Evaluation - Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)

questions.question: An arrow, when shot from the bow, possesses kinetic energy. Where does the arrow get this kinetic energy from?
questions.answer: When the bow is stretched, work is done on it and this work is stored as potential energy in the stretched bow (elastic potential energy). When the arrow is released, this potential energy of the stretched bow is converted into kinetic energy of the arrow. The arrow gains speed and moves forward with kinetic energy.
questions.source_section: Evaluation - Higher Order Thinking Skills (HOTS)

questions.question: The energy of a freely falling body is conserved. Explain.
questions.answer: When a body is held at a height, it has maximum potential energy and zero kinetic energy. As it falls freely, it loses height (potential energy decreases) but gains speed (kinetic energy increases). At any point during the fall, the sum of potential energy and kinetic energy remains constant. Just before hitting the ground, the body has maximum kinetic energy and zero potential energy. Throughout the fall, total mechanical energy (PE + KE) remains constant, demonstrating the law of conservation of energy.
